column1: Mathoms was an old word of the Hobbitish
column2: not recorded as being in use outside the Shire. It was used to refer to "trinkets" or any item that had no particular immediate use.

column1: Mathoms were many of the presents that passed from hand to hand by the Shire-hobbits - an important part of their culture - and whose owners did not wish to throw them away.
Eventually they were stored in the Mathom-house in Michel Delving.
Mathom is a word invented by J.R.R. Tolkien
column2: constructed from an obsolete Old English word máðm "treasure

column1: It is used as a rendering of the original Hobbitish word kast.
